awd_titl_txt: Modeling of Natural Plant Materials to Enable Performance Evaluation of Environmentally Friendly Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
Research has shown that building green roofs have the potential to reduce energy demand on space conditioning, reduce storm water runoff, expand the lifetime of roofing membranes, improve air quality, and reduce the urban heat island effect in cities. Predictive methods to quantify the benefits of green roofs? capabilities to reduce energy consumption and water runoff are needed. The long-term goal of the proposed research is to develop and verify the methods and tools that can be used to calculate heat/mass transfer through a building envelope covered with natural plant material for a given location in the United States. The goal of the present study is to provide tools and calculation methods to quantify summer cooling effects of a green roof, which presently is the most popular natural plant material for buildings. 

The performance of green roofs is climate dependent and having a reliable estimate on potential energy savings is vital in evaluating the investment in this technology. The laboratory experimental methodology to be refined in this project can be applied to other natural plant materials to be incorporated into building envelopes in the future. Furthermore, the impact of the GREEN educational component will not be limited to the two participating schools, but rather an entire community of teachers and students interested in exploring environmental issues. In the future, research results of the present study will be transferable to other diverse natural materials to be integrated not only on building roofs, but also on building vertical walls.

por.por_cntn:
This research team examined performance of green roofs as a building material in several different settings, from laboratory to small and large building installations. We managed to full understand how the incoming solar radiation is treated by plants installed on a roof, so that building designers can predict how the plants would affect the overall building energy consumption and therefore be able to inform a building owner what type of a return on investment for a green roof installation is possible.

 

This project also demonstrated how smart the plants are in managing the water resources available to them in addition to providing shading for the building roof. Plants use very little water when resources are scares, and a lot of water when there is an abundance of water, so they manage water in a way that is responding to the water availability and in such way protect building roof from solar heating for much longer periods of time than if they did not consider water availability. Plants use water in a process called evpotranspiration, which is mostly responsible for building roof protection during the peak solar irradiation. Both shading and evapotranspiration can significantly reduce impact of an incoming heat wave into the building through the roof structure, especially if the roof is uninsulated. For insulated roofs, the heat reduction is not that significant, but plants still help reduce the local air temperatures and manage the water run off during and after the storm events.

 

This project provided green roof models to the research community and our team members have received three different research awards for this work from the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE). Furthermore, National Science Foundation (NSF) created a video about this project that is now a part of the video collection called “Green Revolution” tailored for high school audiences to increase their interest in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics). Finally, our experiment specifically designed and built for this project to test green roofs under controlled environmental conditions have been visited by hundreds of Penn State students, representatives from several dozen companies, and even the president Obama and his administration officials. Overall, the project provided award-wining scientific results as well as public insights into research process and performance of green roofs. The permanent public repository of this project outcomes is hosted in the following web site:

http://www.buildsci.us/modeling-of-natural-plant-materials-to-enable-performance-evaluation-of-environmentally-friendly-buildings.html
